poem:
A Year, Unfurled

In the morning's light,  
hope once cradled, lingers shy—  
a red rose wilts.  
Voices murmur promises  
burdened with forgetfulness.  
Wisps of change breeze through,  
a nation's breath unsteady,  
yet underneath the crumpled leaf,  
roots whisper: wait.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I was naive in being hopeful’: Labour voters feel let down after first year Labour supporters have told the Guardian of their dissatisfaction with the party’s first year in government, as Keir Starmer marks 12 months since becoming the first Labour prime minister since Gordon Brown. Members and voters said initial optimism had given away to unhappiness about the government’s record, although many were keen to state the positives they felt had been forgotten under". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
